page.title: 18LOCAL HISTORY - FORRES EAST
page.content: The site of the Tolbooth has always been the same. It is impossible to say when the first Tolbooth at Forres, was erected. As far back as the Forres Records extend, the meetings of the Provost, Magistrates, and Town Councillors are reported as being convened in the Tolbooth. At the bottom of the Tolbooth is a jail which is no longer used and very important scrolls or books are locked up in the back of the room. The inside is set out like a court room with the judge's chair in the middle at the back. The foundation stone of the present Tolbooth was laid in 1838. The architect for the building was William Robertson whose design was based on that of the previous eartly eighteenth century building on the same site. The adjoining former prison was completed about 1849.
